awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Local Adaptation in a Dominant Arctic Tundra Sedge (Eriophorum Vaginatum) and its Effects on Ecosystem Response in a Changing Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Local adaptation in a dominant arctic tundra sedge (Eriophorum vaginatum) and its effects on ecosystem response in a changing climate

Eriophorum vaginatum is presently a dominant component of moist tussock tundra, but is susceptible to competition from more rapidly growing deciduous shrubs under warming conditions. The project has three objectives: 1) to investigate the genetic factors that lead to local adaptation in E. vaginatum; 2) to examine natural disturbance as a mechanism for genotypes from warmer climates to establish in tussock tundra of northern regions; and 3) to test the hypothesis that local adaptation and adaptational lag will have important consequences for plant phenology, photosynthesis, primary productivity, plant growth, and nutrient cycling. The findings of this project may serve as an indicator of the potential effects of adaptational lag on plant responses to climate change. Research results will be integrated into the manual for the International Tundra Experiment, which has been a developing resource for long term Arctic research. The project directly involves undergraduate research experience for students at Wilkes, a largely undergraduate university, and University of Texas at El Paso, a minority serving institution. Marine Biological Laboratory also will involve students in the research directly through their Semester in Environmental Sciences program, which will involve students in analyzing data taken directly from the Arctic project. K-12 students in Wilkes-Barre will be involved in Arctic research by studying plants shipped from Alaska. K-12 students in El Paso will be exposed to Arctic research through already established programs that engage graduate students with high school students through presentations of research results.

The proposed research will use approaches from molecular ecology and population biology to investigate the causes of local adaptation in Eriophorum vaginatum. It will use methods of ecosystem ecology to investigate the consequences of local adaptation for the response of E. vaginatum to a rapidly warming climate. Genetic markers will be used to determine patterns of genetic diversity and gene flow for populations of E. vaginatum in northern Alaska. Uncovering the underlying genetic structure and population genetic dynamics will provide important insight into the ability for E. vaginatum to adapt to a changing climate. A recent burn site will be seeded with E. vaginatum from different populations with measures of seedling establishment and health followed by identifying genotype success utilizing molecular markers. The processes will be measured in gardens that include both transplants and plants exposed to warming with open-top chambers to simulate the combined effects of northward migration of southern ecotypes and climate warming.

por.por_cntn:
The North Slope of the Brooks Range in Alaska is a vast region about the size and shape of the Florida Peninsula that is home to caribou, grizzly bears, and about 10,000 people. Most of the North Slope is covered by a carpet of tundra, which consists of grasses, sedges, shrubs, mosses, and lichens, but no trees. Under this carpet is a layer of peat that could double the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere if it were to decompose in a warming climate. Viewed from the air, the carpet appears to consist of nubs with spaces in between them. The nubs are actually tussocks of cottongrass (Eriophorum vaginatum), a member of the sedge family. Closeup, a tussock looks like a clump of grass about 20 cm (8 inches) in diameter and 15 cm (6 inches) tall. A tussock is composed of 200-600 tillers or shoots.

    Our project examined the response of locally adapted populations of cottongrass to climate change. Such populations are designated ecotypes if they display differences in their morphology or physiology that appear to have a genetic basis. Ecotypes that are adapted to local conditions may become unable to maintain themselves as climate changes. This phenomenon, called adaptive lag, is potentially significant for Arctic ecosystems where the climate is warming rapidly and where ecotypes of cottongrass occupy large areas. One well-established method for determining whether a plant species has ecotypes is to set up a reciprocal transplant experiment, where plants from one site are exchanged with plants from a different site. To control for the effect of transplanting, plants from each site are also transplanted back into their home site. This allows the investigator to separate the effects of the genetic background from the effects of the environment where the plants are located.

    In 1980 we set up a reciprocal transplant experiment along the Dalton Highway in Alaska that showed that tiller size and flowering displayed local adaptation, whereas survival and growth rates displayed adaptive lag. These results indicated that there were two ecotypes, one on the North Slope and the other south of the Brooks Range. More recently, we analyzed genetic variation of cottongrass along the highway and found significant differences between the northern and southern ecotypes. When the ecotypes were planted in a common garden, the leaves of northern populations stared to turn yellow two weeks earlier than did those from southern populations, which suggests they were adapted to a shorter growing season. Thus, northern and southern populations of tussock cottongrass have distinct characteristics which help them adapt to the climate in their respective regions of Alaska. In a second reciprocal transplant experiment established in 2014, production of new plant tissue for tussocks from warmer southern sites was more sensitive to transplanting than it was for tussocks from northern sites, suggesting that ecotypic control of plant production may affect the response of ecosystem production to climate change. As the climate warms, the movement of genes from south to north is likely to be limited for this long-lived species, and the probability of adaptation to the warming climate through natural selection is not great.  Instead, the abundance of tussock cottongrass may decline, followed by its replacement by shrubs. Because of the important role of this species in the Arctic tundra ecosystem, patterns of plant production as well as nutrient mobilization and use are also likely to change. In turn, this may affect the stability of the peat layer, leading to greater emissions of the greenhouse gases carbon dioxide and methane.

  Undergraduates and recent graduates from Brown University, Florida International University, Haverford College, University of Texas-El Paso, West Chester University, and Wilkes University participated in the project as field and laboratory assistants. The project supported three postdoctoral associates who currently hold positions at the University of Stirling, Babson College, and West Chester University. Students from local high schools in Wilkes-Barre, PA, assisted with experiments on the Wilkes University campus.
